newsitem.title: USA: U.S. foreign crudes facing moderate Gulf demand.
newsitem.headline: U.S. foreign crudes facing moderate Gulf demand.

text.p: U.S. foreign crudes faced some moderate demand at the Gulf Coast helped by a narrow Atlantic arbitrage and relatively high refinery output.
Regional sellers were seen more aggressive than those with European or West African cargoes, suggesting economics for trans-Atlantic sales were confined to large players.
A U.S. trader who purchased a September 8-10 Brent fob on Monday was seen reselling that cargo at similar levels today, at September Brent minus 25 cents.
"It's a tight profit margin, and there are enough domestic supplies around," a Houston trader said.
Regional grade differentials were buoyant with Colombia's Ecopetrol heard selling two cargoes of Cusiana recently.
One end September cargo was reportedly traded at Oct WTI minus 12 cents fob, up from recent trade at minus 27 cents.
Oriente was on offer for mid-September loading at WTI minus $1.75 cif, also a shade stronger.
Rumors of another Alaska North Slope cargo being deiverted to the U.S. Gulf from the saturated West Coast surfaced, but this was flatly denied by the alleged seller.
Traders remained uncertain how depressed sour prices could beco,Tme upon the sale of Iraqi crude oil.
In other regional talk, heavy, sweet Argentine Mendanitos was shown into the U.S. at 50 cents premium to WTI for mid Oct arrival.
Aftermarket hours saw Oct Brent partials changing hands at $20 and $19.97, 100 lots apiece.
Brent Sep/Oct intermonth spreads traded at 40 and 45 cents, traders said.
